paper_abstract: Given two graphs G and H, we investigate for which functions p=p(n) the random graph Gn,p (the binomial random graph on n vertices with edge probability p) satisfies with probability 1-o(1) that every red-blue-coloring of its edges contains a red copy of G or a blue copy of H. We prove a general upper bound on the threshold for this property under the assumption that the denser of the two graphs satisfies a certain balancedness condition. Our result partially confirms a conjecture by the first author and Kreuter, and together with earlier lower bound results establishes the exact order of magnitude of the threshold for the case in which G and H are complete graphs of arbitrary size. In our proof we present an alternative to the so-called deletion method, which was introduced by Rodl and Ruciski in their study of symmetric Ramsey properties of random graphs (i.e. the case G = H), and has been used in many proofs of similar results since then.Copyright (c) 2012 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. Random Struct. Alg., 44, 1-28, 2014
paper_title: Upper Bounds on Probability Thresholds for Asymmetric Ramsey Properties
